leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.6] r 7.6 Representation in cases concerning administration of estates, trust property or statutory interpretation (cf SCR Part 8, rule 14)

leg:heading.title: Representation in cases concerning administration of estates, trust property or statutory interpretation (cf SCR Part 8, rule 14)

p.text: In relation to proceedings concerning:
the administration of a deceased person’s estate, or
property the subject of a trust, or

the construction of an Act, instrument or other document, where a person or class of persons is or may be interested in or affected by the proceedings, the court may appoint one or more of those persons to represent any one or more of them.
A person or persons may not be appointed under subrule (1) unless the court is satisfied of one or more of the following:
that the person or class, or a member of the class, cannot, or cannot readily, be ascertained,
that the person or class, or a member of the class, although ascertained, cannot be found,

that, although the person or class, or a member of the class, has been ascertained and found, it is expedient for the purpose of saving expense (having regard to all of the circumstances, including the amount at stake and the degree of difficulty of the issue or issues to be determined) for a representative to be appointed to represent any one or more of them.
For the purposes of this rule, persons may be treated as having an interest or liability:
even if, in relation to one or more of them, the interest or liability is a contingent or future interest or liability, or
even if one or more of those persons is an unborn child.
This rule does not limit the operation of rule 7.10 .

The purpose of this rule is to allow, in the classes of proceedings to which it applies, a representative to be appointed whenever it is expedient: May v Newton (1887) 34 Ch D 347 at 350 ; Re Gardiner; Jones v Gardiner [1887] WN (Eng) 59; Templeton v Leviathan Pty Ltd (1921) 30 CLR 34; 28 ALR 95 .

level.toc-caption: [7.6.10] Administration of estates — will construction suits

heading.title: Administration of estates — will construction suits

p.text: In proceedings for a declaration as to the construction of an Act, the usual defendant is the person or head of department administering the Act. See McColl v Ryan [1968] 3 NSWR 342; (1968) 89 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 74 ; Australia & New Zealand Bank Ltd v Ryan [1968] 3 NSWR 118; (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 368 (Registrar of Companies); Heritage Fund Ltd v Supervisor of Loan Fund Companies (1977) 3 ACLR 75 ; China Mutual Steam Navigation Co v Maclay [1918] 1 KB 33 ; but see Armstrong v Victoria (No 2) (1957) 99 CLR 28 at 36; [1957] ALR 889 . If there is no other proper defendant, the Attorney-General should be the defendant: Reitzes de Marienwert (Baron) v Administrator of Austrian Property [1924] 2 Ch 282 at 296 ; Re Chillagoe Railway & Mines Ltd [1930] WN 41.

level.toc-caption: [7.6.20] Approval of compromises in representative proceedings

heading.title: Approval of compromises in representative proceedings

p.text: The court may refuse to sanction a compromise where no prima facie case is shown by the plaintiff: Constantinidi v Ralli [1935] 1 Ch 427. Otherwise absent and represented parties may be bound by a compromise: Re Wrigglesworth [1901] WN 172; Saragossa Co v Collingham [1904] AC 159 ; Re Lord Hylton's Settlement [1954] 2 All ER 647 . Dissentients, however, cannot be so bound: Collingham v Sloper [1894] 3 Ch 716 .
Legislation cited in [7.6.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.10(2)(b), r 7.6(2)(c).

It will usually be desirable that the person appointed as a representative consents to acting in that capacity. However the present rule, unlike UCPR r 7.10(2)(b) , does not make consent a pre-condition to appointment. The ultimate consideration in UCPR r 7.6(2)(c) is one of expedience for the purpose of saving expense having regard to all of the circumstances including the amount at stake and the degree of difficulty or the issue or issues to be determined. In an appropriate case, a representation order may be made under the present rule, even against the opposition of the proposed representative: Basis Capital Funds Management Ltd v BT Portfolio Services Ltd (2008) 66 ACSR 580; [2008] NSWSC 555; BC200804386 (appointment of a representative of unit holder beneficiaries). Considerations affecting the decision include, whether one of the candidates is more able to enforce any of the relevant rights or obligations in question or has a commercial and financial interest in the outcome: ING Funds Management Ltd v JP Morgan Nominees Australia Ltd (2009) 69 ACSR 605; [2009] NSWSC 59; BC200900699 per Barrett J (appointment of a representative of unit holder beneficiaries, neither of two candidates wished to be appointed, each submitted that the other was an appropriate appointee, the plaintiff was content to see either appointed).

The form of order will depend on the particular circumstances. Where the relevant parties-to-be represented have been ascertained and notified it may be sufficient to simply make an order for representation. In other cases it may be desirable to require specific notification of the fact and consequences of a representative order: for example, JD Thompson Personnel Pty Ltd v Asgard Capital Management Ltd [2011] NSWSC 811; BC201105770 at [18] (detailed orders — notice of right to apply for joinder — details of the identity, and contact details, of the representative party’s solicitors).

level.toc-caption: [7.6.30] Representative orders relating to defendants — other cases

heading.title: Representative orders relating to defendants — other cases

p.text: There may be a more general basis for (and the former UCPR rr 7.4(1) and 7.4(3) contemplated) representative orders in relation to defendants who have the same liability for a plaintiff’s claim: Amos Removals & Storage Pty Ltd v Small [1981] 2 NSWLR 525 (union members defendants in a conspiracy action); Taff Vale Railway Co v Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants [1901] AC 426 at 438 , 439, 443; London Association for Protection of Trade v Greenlands Ltd [1916] 2 AC 15 at 30; [1916–17] All ER Rep 452 . Similarly, a representative order may be appropriate where the defendants are sought to be made liable on related contracts: Irish Shipping Ltd v Commercial Union Assurance Co Plc [1991] 2 QB 206; [1989] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 144 (claims against multiple insurers); Bank of America National Trust Association v Taylor [1992] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 484 (multiple insurers). However, the class of defendants must be capable of reasonable definition: Roche v Sherrington [1982] 2 All ER 426; [1982] 1 WLR 599 (representative action against world membership of Opus Dei held improperly constituted).

It is very uncommon to obtain an injunction against a representative party. Even if the actual names of alleged wrongdoers are not known, an injunction can still be granted in relation to their impugned conduct: McPhail v Persons, Names Unknown [1973] Ch 447; [1973] 3 All ER 393; [1973] 3 WLR 71 ; Electricity Commission of New South Wales v Arrow (NSWSC, Hodgson J, 5561/90, 7 December 1990, unreported, BC9001680) at 9–10. And the potential efficacy of such an order is arguably aided by the general proposition that a person who is not a party to proceedings but, knowing of an injunction, commits or procures an act to which the injunction applied, is liable to be dealt with for contempt: Z Ltd v A–Z [1982] QB 558; [1982] 1 All ER 556; [1982] 2 WLR 288 ; Attorney-General (UK) v Newspaper Publishing Plc [1988] Ch 333; [1987] 3 All ER 276; [1987] 3 WLR 942 .

In order to justify a representative order for the purpose of proceedings claiming injunctive relief there must be sufficient evidence to establish a likely unity of interest between the persons to be represented, and also their apprehended combination in the use of unlawful means: News Group Newspapers v Society of Graphical and Allied Trades (No 2) [1987] ICR 181 ; [1986] IRLR 337 ; Electricity Commission of New South Wales v Arrow, (NSWSC, Hodgson J, 7 December 1990, unreported, BC9001680) at 8–9. An injunction may be granted against defendants who represent a class: M Michaels (Furriers) v Askew (1983) 127 Sol Jo 597 ; United Kingdom Nirex Ltd v Barton (QBD, Henry J, 18 October 1986, unreported); and see Electricity Commission of New South Wales v Arrow, above, at 6–8. But not to restrain members of an unincorporated association from the commission of separate tortious acts: Clark v University of Melbourne [1978] VR 457 (reversed in part on another point in Clark v University of Melbourne (No 2) [1979] VR 66 ); Geddes v Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union (1917) 17 SR (NSW) 119; 34 WN (NSW) 42 .

If injunctive relief is sought against a person who has both a personal and a potential representative role, it will normally be appropriate to appoint another person as the representative: Electricity Commission of New South Wales v Arrow, above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.7] r 7.7 Judgments and orders bind represented persons in estate and trust property proceedings (cf SCR Part 8, rule 14)

leg:heading.title: Judgments and orders bind represented persons in estate and trust property proceedings (cf SCR Part 8, rule 14)

p.text: A judgment or order made in proceedings in which a party has, by an order under rule 7.6 , been appointed to represent a number of persons or members of a class of persons, binds all such persons, and all members of such a class, as if they had been parties to the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.8] r 7.8 Court may determine who has conduct of proceedings (cf SCR Part 8, rule 17; DCR Part 7, rule 14; LCR Part 6, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Court may determine who has conduct of proceedings (cf SCR Part 8, rule 17; DCR Part 7, rule 14; LCR Part 6, rule 15)

p.text: The court may give the conduct of the whole or any part of any proceedings to such person as it thinks fit.

The representative party usually retains conduct of the litigation until judgment, unless there are special reasons for ordering the contrary. Where there is more than one representative, they must act together: Leathley v McAndrew [1876] WN 38. The court, however, has a wide discretion under this rule and may give the conduct of the proceedings to a represented party who has a particular interest: Re Prince (1883) 48 LT 208. In that regard, a solvent person is preferred to an insolvent one: Re Hopkins; David v Hawtin (1881) 19 Ch D 61 ; an admitted creditor to a disputed one: Re Ross; Wingfield v Blair [1907] 1 Ch 482 ; and a separate creditor to a joint one: Re McRae (1883) 25 Ch D 16 . Conduct is never given to a person who is interested as a receiver of the relevant interests: Re Hopkins, above; The Mersey [1901] P 369; Re Services Club Estate Syndicate Ltd [1930] 1 Ch 78 ; Re Rhodesia Goldfields Ltd [1910] 1 Ch 239 at 240 . A person who opposes being represented by the particular plaintiff, or who is dissatisfied with the representative's conduct of the proceedings, may apply either to become a separate defendant or for an order appointing the defendant as a separate representative: John v Rees [1970] Ch 345 ; Wilson v Church (1878) 9 Ch D 552 ; Fraser v Cooper, Hall & Co (1881) 21 Ch D 718; May v Newton (1887) 34 Ch D 347 . Such an application must be made promptly: Conybeare v Lewis (1883) 48 LT 527. The representative party with the conduct of the proceedings may compromise, discontinue or submit to judgment. After judgment, the representative party loses this power: Re Alpha Co Ltd [1903] 1 Ch 203 ; Re Calgary and Medicine Hat Land Co Ltd [1908] 2 Ch 652 at 659 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.9] r 7.9 Judgments and orders bind beneficiaries (cf SCR Part 8, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Judgments and orders bind beneficiaries (cf SCR Part 8, rule 15)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings that have been commenced by or against a trustee, executor or administrator, including proceedings to enforce a security by way of foreclosure or otherwise.
It is not necessary to join as a party any of the persons having a beneficial interest under the trust, or in the estate, concerned.

Subject to subrule (4), any judgment that is given, and any order that is made, is as binding on a person having a beneficial interest under the trust, or in the estate, as it is binding on the trustee, executor or administrator.

If, in relation to proceedings in which such a judgment or order has been made, the court is satisfied that the representative, trustee, executor or administrator did not in fact represent some or all of the persons having a beneficial interest under the trust, or in the estate, the court may order that the judgment or order does not bind those persons.
This rule does not limit the power of the court to order that a party be joined under rule 6.24 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.10] r 7.10 Interests of deceased person (cf SCR Part 8, rule 16; DCR Part 7, rule 13; LCR Part 6, rule 14)

leg:heading.title: Interests of deceased person (cf SCR Part 8, rule 16; DCR Part 7, rule 13; LCR Part 6, rule 14)

p.text: This rule applies to any proceedings in which it appears to the court:
that a deceased person’s estate has an interest in the proceedings, but is not represented in the proceedings, or
that the executors or administrators of a deceased person’s estate have an interest in the proceedings that is adverse to the interests of the estate.
The court:
may order that the proceedings continue in the absence of a representative of the deceased person’s estate, or
may appoint a representative of the deceased person’s estate for the purposes of the proceedings, but only with the consent of the person to be appointed.

Any order under this rule, and any judgment or order subsequently entered or made in the proceedings, binds the deceased person’s estate to the same extent as the estate would have been bound had a personal representative of the deceased person been a party to the proceedings.
Before making an order under this rule, the court may order that notice of the application be given to such of the persons having an interest in the estate as it thinks fit.

level.toc-caption: [7.10.5] Proceedings in the absence of a representative

heading.title: Proceedings in the absence of a representative

p.text: The court should appoint a representative, or allow the joinder of an executor or administrator, where a sole defendant dies: see [6.30.15]. It is at least doubtful whether proceedings of that kind should be continued in the absence of any representative of the deceased person: Ivanovski v Perdacher [2009] NSWSC 913; BC200908095 at [38] and [49]. The court may proceed in the absence of a representative in various circumstances — including where there are other parties to the proceedings who have the same interest as the estate: Borough of Drummoyne v Hogarth (1906) 23 WN (NSW) 243 (beneficiaries of the estate); where the deceased’s interest is small, contingent or unlikely to be adversely affected by the outcome of the proceedings: Steinecke (bht Gardos) v Wayne [2011] NSWSC 428; BC201103356 (proceedings to appoint trustees for sale); or where the deceased has no practical beneficial interest in the property involved in the proceedings: Curtius v Caledonian Fire & Life Insurance Co (1881) 19 Ch D 534 (equitable mortgagee of an insurance policy — mortgage debt greater than policy benefit — mortgagee claiming under policy); Crossley v City of Glasgow Life Assurance Co (1876) 4 Ch D 421 at 427 ; Porters v Cessnock City Council [2005] NSWSC 1275; BC200510992 (estate vendor under executory contract for sale — small fund — estate beneficiaries unknown). See also May v Newton (1887) 34 Ch D 347 at 350 ; Ballard v Milner [1895] WN 14 (Eng); Hayward v Pile (1872) LR 7 Ch App 634. Where any delay is occasioned by there being no legal personal representative, an award of interest may be refused: Webster v British Empire Mutual Life Assurance Co (1880) 15 Ch D 169.

The court may appoint any person it considers appropriate — subject to the person’s consent: Re Curtis & Betts [1887] WN 126; Pratt v London Transport Board [1937] WN 43; Lean v Alston [1947] KB 467 ; Re Hart; Smith v Clarke [1963] NSWR 627; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 1120 . However, proceedings must be on foot and no appointment should be made if the deceased has a disinterested executor or administrator: Darrington v Caldbeck (1990) 20 NSWLR 212 ; Atsas v Gertsch (NSWSC, Hodgson CJ in Eq, No 2962/97, 28 July 1998, unreported, BC9803443). Normally the appointed representative would be appointed administrator ad litem: Dean & Chapter of Ely v Gayford (1853) 51 ER 896; 16 Beav 561 ; but this is not an inflexible requirement — see [7.10.25] .

Appropriate forms of order are set out in Re Hart; Smith v Clarke [1963] NSWR 627 at 631; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 1120 , for example, “I order that the plaintiff X be appointed to represent the estate of the plaintiff Y, deceased, for the purposes of this suit” or “I order that the defendant X be appointed to represent the estate of Y, deceased, for the purposes of this suit”. The application should be supported by evidence disclosing the propriety of the appointment, the consent of the appointee and the fitness of the appointee to act, and if the person sought to be appointed is not already a party to this suit, the order should provide that the title to the proceedings is amended so as to contain the name of the person appointed, for example, “AB appointed by order dated to represent the estate of CD deceased”, and the words “since deceased” also be added after the name of the party whose estate is represented.

level.toc-caption: [7.10.20] Family provision applications by executor or administrator

p.text: Legislation cited in [7.10.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Sch J.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 7.

heading.title: Family provision applications by executor or administrator

p.text: The specific provisions made in Sch J of the Supreme Court Rules contemplate that an executor or administrator who makes a family provision claim may continue in office (SCR Sch J, Family Provision Act 1982 (now repealed) and Succession Act 2006). If such a plaintiff is a sole executor or administrator, then no defendant should be named (SCR Sch J Family Provision Act 1982 (now repealed) cl 6; SCR Sch J Succession Act 2006 cl 1). The court will provide a contradictor under the representative order provisions in UCPR Pt 7 : Collison v Collison (NSWSC, 4844 of 1994, McLaughlin M, 28 March 1995 unreported, BC9504491) cited with approval by Campbell J in O’Brien v McCormick [2005] NSWSC 619; BC200504652 ; Stedman v O’Hearn [2006] NSWSC 1122; BC200608504 at [5] . Where one of several executors is a plaintiff in family provision proceedings, the court may make a representative order appointing the other(s) to represent the estate for the purposes of the family provision proceedings: Stedman v O’Hearn [2006] NSWSC 1122; BC200608504 . In practice the remaining executors/administrators are often named as defendants without a formal representation order actually being made: Stedman v O’Hearn [2006] NSWSC 1122; BC200608504 at [6] .

level.toc-caption: [7.10.25] Family provision claims where no grant of representation

p.text: Legislation cited in [7.10.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 s 66, s 91.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.10(2)(a), r 7.10(2)(b).

heading.title: Family provision claims where no grant of representation

p.text: A person may obtain a grant of administration for the purposes of bringing a family provision claim: Succession Act 2006 s 91 . However, a grant under s 91 does not entitle the grantor to administer the estate. The usual practice following such a grant is that the court, when hearing the proceedings, appoints an authorised representative for the estate. Either a party can be appointed as authorised representative of the estate pursuant to UCPR r 7.10(2)(b) for the purposes of representing the estate’s interest in the proceedings, or an order can be made pursuant to r 7.10(2)(a) that the proceedings continue in the absence of a representative of the estate. Such orders bind any person who subsequently obtains a grant of probate or administration. In the absence of such a grant, any problems of enforcement of orders may be met by the making of appropriate vesting orders under Succession Act 2006 s 66 : Hewitt v Gardner [2009] NSWSC 705; BC200906495 at [13], [15]–[18] per Ward J (an order made under UCPR r 7.10(2)(a) that the family provision proceedings continue in the absence of a representative of the estate, subject only to there being formal notification to an interested person of the proceedings) citing Re Estate of Harriett Cassel [2000] NSWSC 294; BC200001708 at [7]–[9] per Young CJ in Eq ; Vukic v Grbin [2006] NSWSC 41; BC200600468 at [4], [47] per Breteton J.
